speaker: DR. KEATS
line: Here, let me do it. Put your number in, then your card. What's your number, Roland?

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: See how easy it is?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Engine efficiency?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: We need more. How's the backpressure holding?

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: What do you think? It's climbing.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Increase the blade inclination. I said, increase the blade inclination!

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: The inclination of the blade is pi over 9. We've reached maximum velocity.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: No. Let it go! It will work!

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: The engine's going to destroy itself! I'm not going to do that!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: It's not going to destroy itself. Come on, we're almost there!

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: There's something wrong with our equation.

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: What happened?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Nothing. Because Surnow pulled the plug.

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: I'm just protecting the baby... and four years of work, Frank!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Four years of work that's going to add up to zilch, because unless we show some progress, they're going to pull the plug on us, Ron.

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: He's right, you know. We should have continued with the test.

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: Somebody's going to crack Mach 15, and I want that someone to be us. I'm not going to jeopardize everything just because you two guys can't wait to see your name in print!

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: It's the print that gets the money, Ron.

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: If you want to go down in flames together, fine. You go ahead. I'm gonna do the math.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Good night, Dr. Keats.

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: What the hell?

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: Roland, open the door. Open the door. Roland, I want you to listen to me very carefully. We have to open this door, Roland. Stop typing, Roland!

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: Roland, open the door! What are you doing? Open the door!

speaker: DR. SURNOW
line: Roland! Are you listening?

speaker: MULDER
line: How was the wedding?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You mean the part where the groom passed out or the dog bit the drummer?

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you catch the bouquet?

speaker: SCULLY
line: May-be. So is that what you couldn't talk to me about over the phone?

speaker: MULDER
line: The project that everyone says doesn't exist, does exist.

speaker: SCULLY
line: The Icarus project?

speaker: MULDER
line: The next generation in jet engine design, capable of doubling current supersonic speeds using half the fuel. At least in theory.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And Ronald Surnow was an aeronautical scientist who worked on it here at the university.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How close are they?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not sure, but Surnow is the second scientist on the team to die in the last six months.

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK, but how is this an X-file? Mulder, you don't think this has anything to do with UFO technology?

speaker: MULDER
line: There's something unexplainable here, Scully, but it's certainly not unidentifiable.

speaker: MULDER
line: Keats?

speaker: MAN
line: There.

speaker: MULDER
line: Dr. Keats? We're with the FBI. I'm Agent Mulder, this is Agent Scully. We understand you discovered Dr. Surnow this morning.

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: What was left of him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you suppose he became trapped in the wind tunnel?

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: Someone must have shut him in. The door can only be opened or locked from in there.

speaker: SCULLY
line: By computer?

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: We've already been through this with the police. How many times do we have to rehash it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Another member of your team died a short time ago. Isn't that correct?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Yes. Arthur Grable. He was killed in an automobile accident in November. I'm Frank Nollette. I'm also on the project.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you certain it was an accident?

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: What are you driving at?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your work seems to be a perfect target for industrial espionage.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who wrote this?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Ron was working on it when I left.

speaker: MULDER
line: You see, the handwriting here doesn't seem to match any of the other handwriting on the board.

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: It isn't mine.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about Roland Fuller?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Uh, Roland's the, uh, janitor.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, according to the police report, he was the only other person here last night.

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: Roland didn't do that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you know?

speaker: DR. KEATS
line: Let's just say Roland isn't exactly a rocket scientist.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Here.

speaker: TRACY
line: "Tracy."

speaker: ROLAND
line: With stars.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Roland? There are some people here would like to talk with you.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Uh-oh. I went off the paper. Sorry.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: That's all right, Roland. Tracy, would you like to come help me in the TV room?

speaker: TRACY
line: OK.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi, Roland. Do you mind if we sit down?

speaker: ROLAND
line: OK.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks. You mind if we ask you a couple of questions? Do you remember working last night?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Uh-huh.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Do you remember seeing anything unusual? Seeing any strangers? Did, um, did Dr. Surnow or Dr. Keats or Dr. Nollette do anything unusual?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Nope.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You must like stars.

speaker: ROLAND
line: One hundred and forty-seven.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sorry?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Stars.

speaker: MULDER
line: You like numbers, too.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Roland, let me help you.

speaker: ROLAND
line: One, two, three, four, five...

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Roland.

speaker: ROLAND
line: ... seven...

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Is everything ok?

speaker: ROLAND
line: ... eight, nine...

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Roland, are you all right?

speaker: ROLAND
line: ... ten, eleven, twelve, thirteen...

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: What happened?

speaker: ROLAND
line: ... fourteen...

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: What did you say to upset him so?

speaker: ROLAND
line: ... fifteen, sixteen, seventeen...

speaker: ANALYST
line: It's definitely the work of a fourth and distinct individual. Dr. Surnow's, Dr. Keats', and Dr. Nollette's cursive standards don't match what you found on the whiteboard.

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you do me a favor and try this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's something Roland was doodling at the home.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You don't really think that Roland...

speaker: MULDER
line: Besides Nollette and Keats, he's the only person we can prove was in the lab that night.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, but we're talking about a sophisticated fluid dynamics equation. Roland Fuller barely has an IQ of 70.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, you saw his facility with mathematics. Don't some autistic individuals display unusual abilities?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, but even savants behave only as human calculators. I mean, they can perform certain functions but they can't tell you the value of anything or even the meaning of a number.

speaker: ANALYST
line: I hate to take sides, guys, but the bottom line is no. The terminal stroke on the 6, the roof on the 5 - I'm sorry. He didn't write it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: An organic object exposed to liquid nitrogen at minus 320 degrees will become frozen, exhibiting great tensile strength, but is vulnerable to stress from compression or impact. Now, I've seen this demonstrated on a fish before...

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think they'll be performing this experiment on Beakman's World. Has this been dusted?

speaker: DETECTIVE
line: Treat yourself.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully! Look at these files. KMAN, must be Keats.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But look, someone else entered a file under the name Arthur

speaker: MULDER
line: And worked on it for nearly 5 hours.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it couldn't have been Keats. Judging from the rigor

speaker: MULDER
line: So you're saying someone came in here, killed Keats, and then just did some work on an old Dr. Arthur Grable file?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I can't access the ARTHUR file. We're gonna need the password.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How did you know that that...

speaker: MULDER
line: This is Arthur Grable's work on the same fluid dynamics equation the others were working on. Look at all those entries. Someone has been continuing his work in the six months since he died.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How did you know what the password was?

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Roland? Why did you sleep in your clothes last night? Well, let's get you dressed. You have visitors.

speaker: ROLAND
line: I'm not supposed to talk to them.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Who told you that? Remember that talk we had about being shy. These are nice people, Roland.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Roland, you've got more shirts than I do. I think this one would look stylin' today. What do you think?

speaker: ROLAND
line: The green one.

speaker: MULDER
line: The green one?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Please.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mrs. Stodie, can I talk to you a second? See you later, Roland.

speaker: MULDER
line: This one? Here you go. So you like your job at the college, Roland?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Yes.

speaker: MULDER
line: I hear you're very good at it. You remember how you got your job?

speaker: ROLAND
line: A man talked to Mrs. Stodie.

speaker: MULDER
line: What man?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Dr. Grable.

speaker: MULDER
line: Was Dr. Grable nice to you?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Yes.

speaker: MULDER
line: When was the last time you spoke to him? Last week, the day before?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Dr. Grable died.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm sorry.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Yeah. People die. They go away... and they're not supposed to come back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Has Roland ever mentioned the name Arthur?

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: That was Dr. Grable's first name. But we only called him Dr. Grable. I doubt Roland even knew his first name was Arthur.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mrs. Stodie, can I get a copy of Roland's file and past history?

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Our patients' histories are confidential.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I understand, but I have grounds to obtain them, and the less time we have to spend in court, the more time we have to help Roland.

speaker: MULDER
line: Roland Fuller was hired by Arthur Grable. He went to the halfway house specifically to find a mentally challenged person.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you suggesting that Arthur Grable hired Roland in order to use him? And are you suggesting that Arthur Grable is not dead?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, if he had intentions of killing Nollette, Keats and Surnow, why not set it up to appear the least likely suspect?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, but by the look of this, he's hamburger.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe he staged it. That would explain why his work is continuing on, six months after his "death".

speaker: SCULLY
line: This obituary says that Arthur Grable was born in Seattle. His father was a big banker, his mother was active in a number of charities. Only child. Summa cum laude in physics. Doctoral and post-doctoral in aeronautical engineering at Harvey Mudd. Brilliant future, tragically cut short.

speaker: MULDER
line: Roland's also from Seattle. He spent most of his life at the Heritage Halfway House. The identity of his parents has been sealed by the courts. There's very little information on Roland before the age of three. That's when he was put in the Heritage program.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Does it say when he was born?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's also Arthur's birthdate.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Don't you wish you could fly?

speaker: TRACY
line: I can... when I dream. People can do anything in a dream, you know. Once, one time I had a dream we were married and lived in a house. Do you have dreams, Roland?

speaker: TRACY
line: You can tell me. Roland? Who's Arthur?

speaker: TRACY
line: I'm sorry, Roland. I'm sorry!

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland! Roland.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Go away!

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland, what's the matter?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Go away! I don't want to hurt you. Go away! Go away.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is that you?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Yes.

speaker: MULDER
line: Cool 'do. What's the story here?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Um, a quantum physics professor of mine at Harvey Mudd flunked me. He challenged the tenets of one of my theories - a theory I later published in 'Nature'. Anyway, uh, to get back him, one afternoon we decided to take his car apart and put it back together again in his office and left it running.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmmm, an egghead classic.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: It was Arthur Grable's idea.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that Arthur Grable there, sitting on the chair?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was he a practical joker?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: On top of all his brilliance, he had a genius for executing elaborate schemes.

speaker: MULDER
line: Could he be making it seem like a man with a 70 IQ is gaining access to and, uh, operating his old computer files?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Arthur would still have to be alive.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Could he have faked his own death?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: The police report on the auto accident that killed Arthur Grable is woefully incomplete. The dry road surface, no mechanical problems found. The body was never admitted to the county morgue and there was no funeral.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: If, uh, you are trying to suggest that Arthur Grable killed Surnow and Keats and is after me next, you're way off. Art could not have done the murders.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How can you be so certain?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: This is Arthur Grable. Uh, because of the massive internal damage to his body caused by the car accident, we could only preserve the head.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wouldn't your client find it somewhat inconvenient to be thawed out in the future, only to discover he had no functional mobility?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: We believe that by the time science figures a way to revive our clients...

speaker: MULDER
line: ... you'll also know how to clone new bodies for them.

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: Exactly. This technology is progressing faster than anyone thought possible. Ask anyone here at the university. So, while for us the passing of each second brings our bodies closer to death, for our clients it brings them closer to life.

speaker: MULDER
line: These fluctuations in temperature - do they happen often?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: No, we've had some problems with Dr. Grable's capsule, and the technicians have checked it for possible malfunctions but they found nothing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Is it possible the brain is causing the fluctuation?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: No, but we are looking for the explanation. The patient's in no danger. He remains perfectly preserved as long as there's liquid nitrogen in the capsule.

speaker: SCULLY
line: May we take a look at Arthur Grable's records? Thank you. Dr. Barrington, in your conception of future medical science, what requirements will exist to be an organ or tissue donor?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: Same requirements as there are today, compatible genetic make-up. It's best if the donor's related.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Arthur Grable put down only one donor.

speaker: MULDER
line: Roland Fuller and Arthur Grable had the same birthday. I think they're twins.

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Older or younger?

speaker: MULDER
line: Same age, just less hairy and with better eyesight.

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Gotcha. And the moustache?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, lose the whole beard.

speaker: TECHNICIAN
line: Next?

speaker: MULDER
line: Close cropped hair, with a slightly receding widow's peak. Lose the glasses.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's Roland.

speaker: MULDER
line: Give or take a few pounds.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Tell me about your dreams, Roland. It's all right, I won't tell anybody. You know, I had a dream last night. I dreamt I was, uh, swimming in this pool. And I could see my father underwater, but when I dove down, the water stung my eyes. Then there was another man at the pool, watching me. He upset me. He was asking me questions I didn't want to answer. And I had to leave. I couldn't find my father.

speaker: ROLAND
line: I can't tell you my dreams.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why not?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Bad.

speaker: MULDER
line: Your dreams are bad, Roland. Not you. You're a good person.

speaker: ROLAND
line: I hit Tracy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Your dreams make you hit Tracy?

speaker: MULDER
line: You know how to work this toy, Roland?

speaker: ROLAND
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now, you see the way you work that toy is like what's happening to you. You're the spaceship, Roland, and your dreams are the controls.

speaker: ROLAND
line: But who... who runs the controls?

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you seen this man recently?

speaker: MULDER
line: Roland! Roland! Roland, stop!

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland!

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland! Roland!

speaker: MULDER
line: We need to arrange to keep Roland under observation.

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland! Roland!

speaker: MULDER
line: He's trying to get away.

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland! Roland!

speaker: MULDER
line: Roland! Roland! Roland! Roland! Roland!

speaker: MULDER
line: Nollette's gone. We should arrange a security guard to find him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, no one's gonna provide you with anything once you explain your theory on how Roland Fuller is capable of these murders.

speaker: MULDER
line: You've got a brother, don't you Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. I've got an older one and a younger one.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, have you ever thought about calling one of them all day long and then all of a sudden the phone rings and it's one of them calling you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Does this pitch somehow end with a way for me to lower my long distance charges?

speaker: MULDER
line: I believe in psychic connections, and evidence suggests that it's stronger between family members, strongest of all between twin siblings that shared the same womb.

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK, maybe. But in this case, one sibling has closer ties to a frozen fudgesicle than he does to his own brother.

speaker: MULDER
line: Arthur Grable is not dead. He's in a state of consciousness that no human has ever returned from. And what if that state allows one to develop psychic ability to a potential that the conscious mind is too preoccupied to explore or believe in? He could use that ability to control his brother to kill those scientists.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But why? He's been working with these colleagues for years.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that's a question that only Dr. Nollette can answer.

speaker: SCULLY
line: OK. Let's go. I have to call my brother.

speaker: MULDER
line: We've got to find Nollette.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let's talk to campus security.

speaker: MULDER
line: We go this way?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, we go left.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Well, wherever you are, Arthur, I'm sure you'll appreciate this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Arthur and Roland Grable, born at Puget Presbyterian to Mr. and Mrs. Louis Grable on July 15, 1952. Arthur was four minutes older than Roland.

speaker: MULDER
line: Identical twins.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Which means that they're the result of a single egg fertilized by a single sperm.

speaker: MULDER
line: I've read studies which suggest that in some cases the identical twin arises very early in the embryonic stage when a mutation in one cell is rejected by the other cells as foreign.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So that maybe Roland's condition is the result of a damaged chromosome rejected by one of Arthur's cells?

speaker: MULDER
line: In a way, that would explain Arthur's genius and Roland's strange mathematical gift.

speaker: SCULLY
line: In a way. Agent Scully.

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: This is Larry Barrington at the Avalon Foundation. We've, uh, got a situation here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh-huh.

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: Last night we had a break-in at the facility. That's right. Yeah, it's Arthur Grable's storage unit. His internal thermostat's been compromised.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was there any tissue damage?

speaker: BARRINGTON
line: We're trying to assess that now. The temperature's still rising. Something's blocking our access to the cooling program.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Someone tampered with Arthur Grable's capsule. They're attempting to stabilize it now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nollette?

speaker: ROLAND
line: What? What is it?

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: "If I've seen further than other men, it's because I have stood on the shoulders of giants."

speaker: ROLAND
line: No. This isn't yours!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: It's amazing. There's this body, sitting there in front of me, talking. But you're controlling it, Arthur.

speaker: ROLAND
line: You... took my work!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: What good was your work going to do you? You died before you could finish it, before you could publish it.

speaker: ROLAND
line: It was mine!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: And a brilliant piece of work, too. When I saw the writing on the whiteboard, I knew someone had found the key. Mach 15 was within our reach. Our futures were guaranteed. Ironic, isn't it? You did all the work, and I get all the glory.

speaker: ROLAND
line: No!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Yes. Yes, Arthur. I was here, working on the intake problem, moments away from a solution when you attacked me. Fortunately, I was carrying a gun. After the murder of my colleagues, who could blame me?

speaker: ROLAND
line: No!

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: That's, that's interesting. I've got it. That's it. I've got it.

speaker: DR. NOLLETTE
line: Arthur! Arthur, open the door! Arthur!

speaker: MULDER
line: Arthur, how do you stop this? Tell me how! Arthur!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wait. Roland, we need you to help us. Please, we need you to help us to stop the machine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Try to remember how. Roland, you've got to help him or he's going to die.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Roland.

speaker: ROLAND
line: I can't remember.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He'll be held in psychiatric custody for evaluation.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: Is he being charged with a crime?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The D.A. hasn't made that determination yet.

speaker: MULDER
line: But we've recommended that he be remanded to your custody as soon as the court deems it appropriate.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: How could this happen? Roland never exhibited any violent tendencies.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's my belief that he wasn't acting under his own volition.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: What do you mean?

speaker: MULDER
line: This is the work of Arthur Grable, Roland's brother. It's a new theory of jet propulsion, unfinished at the time of his death. In the last two weeks, Roland has completed the calculations.

speaker: MRS. STODIE
line: How?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We're not sure, Mrs. Stodie. All we know is that Roland was somehow able to finish his brother's research.

speaker: TRACY
line: Roland? Where are you going? Roland, don't go.

speaker: ROLAND
line: I have to.

speaker: TRACY
line: OK. Fine.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Tracy. Wait.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Keep my stars.

speaker: TRACY
line: I love you.

speaker: ROLAND
line: Me too.
